instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USB on I/O board disabled
threads.message:
Hi, I have a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with 3476 (8GB) board that has has had liquid damage. Its been cleaned and now works apart from the right USB (I/O board) is being disabled due to too much draw. The left usb works fine, even when the right it disabled. 
Keyboard and trackpad work fine. Trackpad had some liquid damage on one of the ribbons initially but that was cleaned off and it sorted the crazy cursor issue.

I've tried with keyboard and trackpad ribbons not connected and its the same. 

I've tried another I/O board and ribbon connector with the same result.

If you plug in a mouse, you get a light but nothing more.

I've seen it once work fine for about 10 seconds after initial boot up, but then it was disabled by the OS
Any ideas as to what I should check would be really appreciated.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USB on I/O board disabled
threads.message: Check voltages on <RESISTOR>R1580</RESISTOR>-83, those are the USB over current alerts to the CPU. One of them will probably be low. Check diode mode on the one that is low.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USB on I/O board disabled
threads.message:
Thank you Duke,

<RESISTOR>R1580</RESISTOR> is 3.28v on <SIGNAL>USB_EXTA</SIGNAL>, 3.33v on PP3v3 - 98.3kohm
<RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR> is 3.21v on <SIGNAL>USB_EXTD</SIGNAL>, 3.33v on PP3v3, - 78.6kohm

Apart from the 78.6kohm on <RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR>, they look pretty okay, maybe 3.21v on <RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR> is a bit low also.

What do you think?

Thanks again for helping, I hope I gave enough info.

------------------------------------------------------------

Diode test

<RESISTOR>R1580</RESISTOR> is 0.420 on <SIGNAL>USB_EXTA</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR> is 0.438 on <SIGNAL>USB_EXTD</SIGNAL>

Both resistors measure 0.301 on PP3v3 pins

------------------------------------------------------------

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USB on I/O board disabled
threads.message: I took off <RESISTOR>R1583</RESISTOR> with the intention of replacing it, but when its off the board, it has 99.8k resistance which it perfect really.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USB on I/O board disabled
threads.message:
Found that pin 1 (<SIGNAL>USB_EXTB</SIGNAL>) on <RESISTOR>R1581</RESISTOR> wasn't actually making contact, so removed that, cleaned the pads and replaced it. The right USB seems to be working now.

Those 0201 resistors aren't great to solder!
